quiz.title: Unit 5: Work & Energy (Quiz 2)
quiz.subtitle: Section E â€” Complete School-Style Questions (50 Problems)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: The students push on a stationary box to accelerate it across the gym floor. In this situation, work is done on the box by the _
options: The floor pushing upward on the box
The Earth's gravity pulling downward on the box
The box pushing backward on the floor
The students applying force to the box
questions.explanation: The applied push causes displacement; the students do positive work on the box.

questions.question: The students push on a stationary box to accelerate it across the gym floor. As a result, the mechanical energy of the box _
questions.explanation: The box gains kinetic energy while accelerating, so its mechanical energy increases.

questions.question: A person lifts a bucket from the ground to a shelf. In this situation, work is done on the bucket by the _
options: Earth's gravity pulling downward on the bucket
The person's force applied upward to the bucket
The shelf pushing upward on the bucket
The bucket pushing downward on the person
questions.explanation: The lifter's upward force through a vertical displacement does positive work on the bucket.

questions.question: A person lifts a bucket from the ground to a shelf. As a result, the mechanical energy of the bucket _
questions.explanation: The bucket gains gravitational potential energy as height increases.

questions.question: A car slows down on a flat road due to friction. In this situation, work is done on the car by _
options: The friction between the tires and the road
The air resistance opposing the car
The force of gravity pulling downward
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is removed by friction doing negative work on the car.

questions.question: A car slows down on a flat road due to friction. As a result, the mechanical energy of the car _
questions.explanation: Friction dissipates mechanical energy as heat and sound; KE decreases.

questions.question: A person pushes a box across a rough floor and it slows down due to friction. In this situation, work is done on the box by _
options: The person applying force to the box
The friction between the box and the floor
The gravitational pull on the box
questions.explanation: Friction opposes motion and does negative work on the box.

questions.question: A person pushes a box across a rough floor and it slows down due to friction. As a result, the mechanical energy of the box _
questions.explanation: Mechanical energy decreases as kinetic energy is converted to heat.

questions.question: A rocket is launched into space. In this situation, work is done on the rocket by _
options: The force of gravity pulling downward
The force exerted by the rocket's engine pushing upward
The air resistance opposing the motion
questions.explanation: The engine's thrust through displacement does positive work on the rocket.

questions.question: A rocket is launched into space. As a result, the mechanical energy of the rocket _
questions.explanation: The rocket gains kinetic and gravitational potential energy while ascending.

questions.question: A ball is dropped and gravity pulls it downward as it falls. All the following forces act on it: Gravity (A) and Air resistance (B). Which of the following options is correct about work done?
options: A does positive work and B does negative work
A does negative work and B does positive work
A does positive work and B does positive work
A does negative work and B does negative work
questions.explanation: Gravity acts in the same direction as the motion of the falling ball, so it does positive work. Air resistance acts opposite to motion, doing negative work.

questions.question: A cyclist pedals uphill on a mountain road, overcoming gravitational pull. As a result, the mechanical energy of the cyclist _
questions.explanation: Gains gravitational potential energy as height increases.

questions.question: A person holds a suitcase stationary while standing on the ground. In this situation, work is done on the suitcase by _
options: The person applying force upward to lift the suitcase
The normal force from the floor supporting the suitcase
No work is done on the suitcase
questions.explanation: With no displacement, work on the suitcase is zero.

questions.question: A person holds a suitcase stationary while standing on the ground. As a result, the mechanical energy of the suitcase _
questions.explanation: No change in speed or height, so mechanical energy is unchanged.

questions.question: A ball is dropped and falls toward the ground. In this situation, work is done on the ball by _
options: The floor pushing upward when the ball hits
The air resistance acting on the ball
The person's hand releasing the ball
questions.explanation: Gravity does positive work while the ball falls.

questions.question: A ball is dropped and falls toward the ground. As a result, the mechanical energy of the ball _
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy increases as the ball accelerates downward.

questions.question: A rocket launches and accelerates upward, overcoming gravity. In this situation, work is done on the rocket by _
options: The force of gravity pulling downward
Air resistance acting against the rocket
questions.explanation: Thrust does positive work on the rocket through upward displacement.

questions.question: A rocket launches and accelerates upward, overcoming gravity. As a result, the mechanical energy of the rocket _
questions.explanation: Both kinetic and gravitational potential energy increase during ascent.

questions.question: A student pushes a cart up a ramp, and friction slows it down. In this situation, work is done on the cart by the student pushing the cart, by friction, and by the force of gravity. In this order, how would you describe the work done?
questions.explanation: Work done by the student is positive, as the applied force is in the same direction as motion. Work done by both friction and gravity are negative, since they act opposite to the direction of motion.
Friction does negative work opposing the cart's motion.

questions.question: A student pushes a cart up a ramp, and friction slows it down. As a result, the mechanical energy of the cart _
questions.explanation: Mechanical energy decreases due to energy dissipated by friction.

questions.question: Starting from rest at the top of the friction-free slide, the child slides down to the bottom. This situation can best be described as a transformation of _
options: Dissipated energy (e.g., heat) into Kinetic energy
questions.explanation: On a friction-free slide, gravitational PE converts entirely to KE.

questions.question: A pendulum swings back and forth in the absence of air resistance. At the highest point, the pendulum has:
questions.explanation: Instantaneous speed is zero at the top; energy is purely gravitational PE.

questions.question: A block slides down a ramp with friction. The transformation of energy can best be described as:
options: Potential energy into kinetic and dissipated energy
questions.explanation: Some PE becomes KE; the rest is lost as heat due to friction.

questions.question: A moving car suddenly applies the brakes and comes to a stop. The energy transformation that occurs is:
options: Gravitational potential energy into dissipated energy
questions.explanation: Braking friction converts KE into thermal energy (and some sound).

questions.question: When a spring is compressed and then released, it transforms:
options: Elastic potential energy into kinetic energy
Gravitational potential energy into chemical energy
Chemical energy into elastic potential energy
questions.explanation: Stored elastic PE converts to KE of the mass when released.

questions.question: A car is fueled by gasoline and starts moving. This is an example of:
options: Chemical energy into kinetic energy and heat energy
Potential energy into kinetic energy and sound energy
Kinetic energy into potential energy and heat energy
questions.explanation: Gasoline's chemical energy is converted into mechanical motion and heat by the engine.

questions.question: In a battery-powered flashlight, the energy transformations are:
options: Chemical energy to electrical energy to light and heat energy
questions.explanation: Chemical energy in the battery becomes electrical energy, which powers the bulb producing light and heat.

questions.question: When a ball is thrown straight up, its energy transformation during ascent is:
questions.explanation: As the ball rises, kinetic energy converts to gravitational potential energy.

questions.question: A child winds up a toy car and releases it. The car moves forward. The energy transformation is:
options: Elastic potential energy to kinetic energy
questions.explanation: The wound spring stores elastic potential energy which is released as kinetic energy.

questions.question: A solar panel converts:
questions.explanation: Solar cells transform sunlight directly into electrical energy.

questions.question: A skier starts from rest at the top of a slope and gains speed as they descend. The energy transformation is:
options: Potential energy into kinetic energy and thermal energy
questions.explanation: Potential energy converts mainly to kinetic energy, with small losses to heat from friction.

questions.question: A fan converts energy from an outlet into motion. The transformation of energy is:
options: Electrical energy into kinetic and sound energy
Chemical energy into light and sound energy
questions.explanation: Electric energy drives the fan's motor, producing motion and sound.

questions.question: When food is digested in the body, the transformation of energy is:
options: Chemical energy into kinetic and thermal energy
questions.explanation: Chemical energy in food powers body movement (kinetic) and heat generation.

questions.question: The lineman push on the weighted sled to accelerate it across the football field:
questions.explanation: Muscular chemical energy is converted into kinetic energy moving the sled.

questions.question: The student lifts the book from the floor and places it on the top shelf of the locker: Describe the energy conversion taking place, given the following: (A) Thermal Energy, (B) Chemical Energy, (C) Electrical Energy, (D) Gravitational Potential Energy, (E) Solar Energy, (F) Kinetic Energy.
options: B, F and A then D
B and D, A then F
B and A, F then D
B, F and D then A
questions.explanation: Chemical energy (B) from the student's muscles produces motion (F, kinetic energy) and heat (A, thermal energy), resulting in an increase in gravitational potential energy (D) of the book.

questions.question: A car with locked wheels skids to a stop while moving along a level highway:
options: Chemical energy into dissipated energy (heat and sound)
Kinetic energy into dissipated energy (heat and sound)
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy converts to heat and sound through friction with the road.

questions.question: A softball player slows to a stop while sliding across the infield dirt into third base:
options: Kinetic energy into dissipated energy (heat and sound)
Chemical energy into dissipated energy (heat and sound)
questions.explanation: Friction converts the player's kinetic energy into heat and sound as they stop.

questions.question: Dad gives the child in the swing a forward push in order to set her into motion. In this situation, work is done on the child by:
options: The frame of the swing holding the swing in place
The seat of the swing holding the child up
The force applied by Dad on the child
The Earth's gravity pulling down on the child
questions.explanation: Dad's push applies an external force that sets the swing in motion.

questions.question: Dad gives the child in the swing a forward push in order to set her into motion. As a result, the mechanical energy of the child _
questions.explanation: The child gains kinetic energy; mechanical energy increases.

questions.question: The downward moving hammer strikes the nail and slows down. In this situation, work is done on the hammer by:
options: The hand pushing downward on the hammer
The hammer pushing downward on the nail
The wood board pushing upward on the nail
The nail pushing upward on the hammer
questions.explanation: The nail exerts an upward force doing negative work on the hammer.

questions.question: The downward moving hammer strikes the nail and slows down. As a result, the mechanical energy of the hammer _
questions.explanation: The hammer's kinetic energy decreases as it slows down.

questions.question: A car with locked wheels skids to a stop while moving along a level highway. In this situation, work is done on the car by:
options: The friction between tires and road
The force of gravity acting upon the car
The road pushing upward on the car
questions.explanation: Friction opposes motion, converting kinetic energy into heat.

questions.question: A car with locked wheels skids to a stop while moving along a level highway. As a result, the mechanical energy of the car _
questions.explanation: Kinetic energy is dissipated as heat and sound; mechanical energy decreases.

questions.question: A student lifts a book from the floor to the top shelf of the locker. In this situation, work is done on the book by:
options: Downward force of the book on the student
Upward force applied by the student to the book
Force of the floor pushing up on the student
Upward force of Earth's gravity on the book
questions.explanation: The student's upward force lifts the book, performing positive work.

questions.question: A student lifts a book from the floor to the top shelf of the locker. As a result, the mechanical energy of the book:
questions.explanation: Raising the book increases its gravitational potential energy.

questions.question: A hiker climbs a hill carrying a backpack. In this situation, work is done on the backpack by:
options: Downward force of gravity on the backpack
Upward force applied by the hiker to the backpack
Friction between the backpack and the hiker's body
Wind resistance pushing against the backpack
questions.explanation: The hiker's upward lift performs work against gravity.

questions.question: A hiker climbs a hill carrying a backpack. As a result, the mechanical energy of the backpack:
questions.explanation: Mechanical energy increases as gravitational potential energy rises with height.

questions.question: A person pushes a box across the floor at a constant speed. In this situation, work is done on the box by:
options: The force exerted by the person on the box
The gravitational force acting on the box
The frictional force between the box and the floor
The upward force exerted by the floor on the box
questions.explanation: The person's horizontal push does work to overcome friction.

questions.question: A person pushes a box across the floor at a constant speed. As a result, the mechanical energy of the box:
questions.explanation: Constant speed means kinetic energy is steady, so mechanical energy stays constant.

questions.question: At which point of the vertical projectile is kinetic energy maximum?
options: At the lowest point of the height
questions.explanation: At launch/ground level, all energy is kinetic; PE = 0 J, KE = 80 J.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent mastery of applied school problems on Work, Energy and Power.
scoreMessages.70: Good progress â€” review mixed transformation cases and conservation principles.
scoreMessages.50: Basic understanding shown â€” practice detailed energy-path reasoning.
scoreMessages.0: Revisit definitions of work, transformation, and conservation of energy.
